title: Are scientific words and vocabularies easy to use or understand? - Quora

response.answer_text: Um… Sort of… If you have been taught/have been in that specific field of ‘science’ long enough, then - yes, the words used (designed/created/common) therein are easy for those in the know. For those (such as myself) who are not in a field using scientific words, say, an astrophysicist or the like, then yes, they are difficult. However, the same applies to almost any field. some using terms such as hot desk or collar and board, to name just a few examples. Does everyone know the meaning of those slangs specific to their fields? Personally, I’ve always liked S.O.B. As anybody/everybody knows, it is short for a swear (son of a b***h) - but nurses mean S.O.B. as Short(ness) Of Breath. How’s that for a technical term? :)

Not for people wgo are trained educated and experienced in the field. That is not to say it is an insurmountable difficulty for a novice! Even an apprentice ( no reference to a pun on trump intended ) and excellent on-site help will lead to an intimate , and usual application of the knowledge of the requisite terminology …or of the appropriate jargon! Tech courses are a desired activity!

No! They are intended to be confusing and irritating to those who are not part of the clique. This began with snobs and continues with them, as well. My husband has a friend in Scotland who told him he could send some scientific papers but he wouldn’t understand them. The friend has a PhD but he couldn’t answer my husband’s questions regarding some of the items contained in the treatises. Science has become a grant-empowered desire to make something of nothing, then seek more grant money to further investigate. Hope this helps, Kat

If it is your science, you learn a concept, and so you as you grasp the concept you brain “wants” to label it ( all words are labels for ideas/concepts anyway) So the answer I give is “only to those who know the science” Good science writing should contain simple direct speech, so from that point of view should be clear and concise. You might check out Plain English Campaign Free guides plainlanguage.gov US Government Intute
Frequently they’re very challenging, but like so many other things in life, if you spend the time to learn them they’re very useful.
